result.execSummary:
The defendant Larry Sanchez Sr. was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Larry Sanchez Sr. is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Larry Sanchez Sr. was found guilty of 1st-Degree Reckless Homicide [Modifiers: Use of a Dangerous Weapon], a class B felony, Wisconsin Statutes 940.02(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Pay 25% or 50% of prison account towards restitution.

If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed as stated by law of gross income.

No contact with the immediate family of Lisa Sanchez including her parents, siblings, children, grandchildren, etc.
Maintain absolute sobriety.
Comply with any other assessments, treatments, and programs as deemed appropriate by the Compas assessment and Dept of Corrections.
Sign necessary releases of information for assessments, medications, pharmacies, and treatments.
Pay all court obligations 90 days prior to discharge.
Provide DNA sample if not already done so.
Restitution shall be paid before any court costs
Complete and AODA assessment and comply with treatment recommendations.
Complete a psychologial assessment and comply with treatment recommendations

from victims

Defendant Larry Sanchez in court with attorney Ryan Drengler and attorney Emily Nolan Plutchak. Defendant Larry Sanchez in custody. Louis John Molepske and Elizabeth Constable appear for the State of Wisconsin.
Exhibits #1-#17 are marked on behalf of the Petitioner and Defense prior to the start of Court.

1:11 PM Court calls case.
Atty Molepske states appearances.
Victims related to this offense are also present.
State has complied with victim notification statutes.
Victims wish to make statements.

Court addresses the parties. Defendant did plead to count as stated. Court ordered a PSI.  One was prepared. Both parties received their copy of the report.
Atty Molepske has no corrections or additional statements as to the PSI.
Atty Drengler has no factual corrections to make but Defense does intend to move to strike certain portions of the PSI that are prejudicial.

Atty Drengler addresses the Court, makes record at this time regarding the PSI, for the record.

Atty Molepske addresses the Court, replies.

BY THE COURT:
Court will deny the request, will not strike any part of the PSI, for reasons stated on the record. Court will give it  the weight it deserves.

Court also received the alternative PSI along with alternative recommendations.
State has received a copy of this, has no corrections from a factual standpoint but has concern as to medical opinions provided by the preparer, for reasons stated on the record.
Atty Drengler addresses the Court, replies. 
Court would put this in the same category as to agent's impressions and will give it the weight it deserves.

There is also a psychiatric evaluation that was done. 
State received a copy of this as well, states one correction as to page 2.

There was also attached a letter from Defendant's older brother and wife.
State received a copy of this as well.

Everyone has all the same information, it is public and being made as the court file.

Defense will not be calling witnesses.
Atty Molepske provides written victim statement to the Court.
Family of the Sanchez would like the Court to consider the written statement. 

1:33 PM Atty Molepske reads the written statements, for the record. 
1:38 PM Court interrupts Atty Molepske, will not allow statements to be directed to Defendant, but only to the Court.
1:38 PM Atty Molepske continues reading.
1:43 PM Court thanks victims for appearing today and for their statements.

State has reviewed the PSI. 
State is requesting 40 years prison.

Atty Molepske addresses the Court, gives sentencing recommendations.
Atty Constable addresses the Court, continues sentencing recommendations.
Exhibits #1-#3 and #15 are referred to.
1:56 PM Atty Molepske continues.
Exhibits  #4, #7-#9, and #16-#17 are referred to. Portion of Exhibits #16 and #17 are played. 
2:22 PM Court questions Atty Molepske, for clarifications.

2:23 PM Atty Drengler addresses the Court, gives sentencing recommendations.
Defense is requesting less years of prison.
Exhibits #10-#14 are referred to.

2:48 PM Atty Nolan Plutchak reads Defendant's statement.

2:50 PM Court has a number of factors to consider to determine an appropriate sentence.


BY THE COURT:
Count 2:
Determinate Prison Sentence for 40 years
Initial Confinement for 30 years
Extended Supervision for 10 years
476 days credit
Not eligible for challenge incarceration
Not eligible for earned release
Conditions:
No contact with the immediate family of Lisa Sanchez including her parents, siblings, children, grandchildren, etc
Complete and AODA assessment and comply with treatment recommendations
Complete a psychologial assessment and comply with treatment recommendations
Maintain absolute sobriety
Comply with any other assessments, treatments, and programs as deemed appropriate by the Compas assessment and Dept of Corrections
Sign necessary releases of information for assessments, medications, pharmacies, and treatments
Pay all court obligations 90 days prior to discharge
Pay restitution in the amount of $8,967.83:
-Mary Lauer - $7,461.87
-Allan Richtmyre - $278.13 and $222.98
-Lance Sanchez - $28.05
-Taryn Lauer - $1,199.78
Court will allow the State 30 days to supplement to the restitution
Pay 25% or 50% of prison account towards restitution
Provide DNA sample if not already done so
Pay court costs
Pay DNA surcharge
Restitution shall be paid before any court costs

20 days in which to appeal the case

Both parties will keep their copies of the PSI, confidential.

Atty Constable addresses the Court regarding restitution requests being calculated.
State requests to hold the restitution open for 30 days.

BY THE COURT:
Court will give the State 30 days to supplement the restitution.
Court will give Defense 30 days after that to request a restitution hearing, if choose to.

State requests Exhibits #7-#9 to be sealed.

BY THE COURT:
Out of respect, the Court will seal Exhibits #7-#9.


All the exhibits are accounted for.
Sentencing Memorandum from Public Defender

Defendant Larry Sanchez in court with attorney Emily M Nolan-Plutchak. Defendant Larry Sanchez in custody.  Louis John Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Case is set for a Motion Hearing to adjourn the sentencing hearing.

8:49 a.m.  Court calls case and states the appearances.
Court states the status of the case.
Atty Nolan-Plutchak makes statements regarding the request to adjourn the sentencing hearing and states these on the record; she also indicates that the defense has requested an independent PSI. 
Atty Molepske states his objection to adjourning the sentencing hearing and states this on the record.
Atty Nolan-Plutchak responds to the statement of Atty Molepske.
Court states its findings on the record.

BY THE COURT:
Request to adjourn the sentencing hearing is DENIED.
letter from Atty Ryan Drengler requesting an adjournment of the sentencing hearing due to the PSI being completed/received late
Sentencing hearing on September 22, 2016 at 01:00 pm.

Defendant Larry Sanchez in court with attorney Ryan Drengler and Atty Emily Nolan Plutchak. Defendant Larry Sanchez in custody. Louis John Molepske and Elizabeth Constable appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
8:42 a.m.  Court calls the case. 

Atty Molepske states the appearances.  Motions will be withdrawn and the defendant will be entering a plea today. 
Court questions Atty Drengler. 
Atty Drengler moves to withdraw the motions for the reasons stated on the record. 

Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Prosecutor states plea agreement.  
Atty Drengler moves to withdraw the Motion for discovery. 
Attorney for Defendant concurs with agreement stated.

Defendant enters a plea of: 
Count 2 - NO CONTEST

Atty Nolan-Plutchak makes statements to the Court.  
Atty Drengler asks the court to amend the plea on the record to Guilty. 
Court questions defendant. 

Defendant now enters a plea of:
Count 2 - GUILTY

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).
State has complied with Victim Notification Statutes. 

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty Count 2.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.
Counts 1 & 3 are dismissed.
Count 4 is dismissed and read-in. 
Court orders a PSI.  

Court questions parties re: length of sentencing hearing. 
Atty Constable makes statements to the Court. 
Atty Drengler makes statements to the Court. 

BY THE COURT:  PSI to be completed by 9/8/2016 with copies forwarded to counsel to prepare for sentencing.  Bond is revoked.  Sentencing hearing scheduled for September 22, 2016 at 01:00 pm.

Defendant Larry Sanchez in court with attorney Travis Stephen Slattery and Emily M Nolan-Plutchak. Defendant Larry Sanchez in custody. Louis John Molepske and Elizabeth Constable appeared for the State of Wisconsin.


3:15 p.m.  Court calls case.
Atty Molepske states the appearances.
Court indicates that this is a motion hearing for leave to withdraw as counsel filed by Atty Slattery.
Atty Slattery makes statements as to why he would prefer to withdraw as counsel for this case on the record.
Court makes additional statements.
Atty Ryan Drengler will be taking the place of Atty Slattery and Atty Nolan-Plutchak will continue on this case.
Court questions if the duties are  to be split equally with 2 attorney's representing the defendant.
Atty Nolan-Plutchak is requesting a new schduling order; Court asks for additional information as to why she needs a new scheduling order and Atty Nolan-Plutchak makes statements.
Court questions the State regarding re-scheduling this case; Atty Molpske makes statements.
State does not object to the re-scheduling of the Jury Trial but is keeping in contact with the victim's family.
Court questions the defendant; defendant does not object to the re-scheduling of the Jury Trial - defendant consults with Atty Nolan-Plutchak.

BY THE COURT: 
Court signs the order allowing Atty Slattery to withdraw as one of the attorney's of record.
Attorney's to do re-scheduling order back in chambers.
Bond and conditions of bond are ordered continued.

Defendant Larry Sanchez in court with attorney Travis Stephen Slattery and Emily Nolan-Plutchak. Defendant Larry Sanchez in custody. 
Louis J. Molepske and Elizabeth Constable appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Exhibit #1 is marked on behalf of the petitioner, prior to the case being called. 

8:34 a.m.  Court calls the case. 
Atty Molepske states the appearances. 
Detective J. Coey is called and sworn. 
Direct exam by Atty Constable. 
Witness identifies the defendant. 
8:50 a.m.  Cross exam by Atty Nolan-Plutchak. 

9:02 a.m.  Coroner S. Rifleman is called and sworn. 
Direct exam by Atty Molepske. 
Exhibit #2 is marked on behalf of the plaintiff and referred to during testimony. 
Moves for the admission of Exhibit #2 and for the sealing of Exhibit #2.  No objection by Atty Nolan-Plutchak. 
Atty Molepske makes arguments to seal this exhibit.  No objection by Atty Nolan-Plutchak. 
BY THE COURT:  Exhibit #2 is received and is ordered sealed. 
Exhibit #1 is referred to during testimony. 
Atty Molepske moves for the admission of Exhibit #1.  No objection by Atty Nolan-Plutchak. 
BY THE COURT:  Exhibit #1 is received. 
9:15 a.m.  Cross exam by Atty Nolan-Plutchak. 

9:18 a.m.  Atty Nolan-Plutchak states objection to bind over. 

BY THE COURT: Court finds it is probable that a felony was committed and this defendant committed it and binds the defendant over for trial.  Bond and conditions of bond are continued.  Arraignment scheduled for October 19, 2015 at 08:30 am.

BY THE COURT:

Defendant Larry Sanchez in court with attorney Travis Stephen Slattery and Emily M Nolan-Pultchak. Defendant Larry Sanchez in custody. Louis J. Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

2:02 p.m.  Court calls case.
Atty Molepske states the appearances.
Court makes statements regarding the report from Dr Galli; all counsel have received their copies.
Court asks the defendant if he is competent or incompetent; Defendant states he is incompetent. 
Atty Molepske states that Dr Galli will be appearing by phone and defense counsel does not object; Clerk places the call.
2:04 p.m.  Dr Galli is on the phone and sworn in by the Court.
Court informs Dr Galli that his report has been received by all parties.
Direct examination by Atty Molepske.
2:14 p.m.  Cross examination by Atty Slattery.
2:23 p.m.  Court informs Dr Galli to slow down a bit.
Atty Slattery continues his cross examination.
2:29 p.m.  Objection by Atty Molepske; questioned already answered by Dr Galli (neither sustained or overruled by the Court)
2:31 p.m.  Objection by Atty Molepske; sustained (Court ruled after hearing question again).
2:32 p.m.  Objection by Atty Molepske; overruled.
2:35 p.m.  Re-direct by Atty Molepske.
2:30 p.m.  Atty Slattery has no re-cross.
2:39 p.m.  Atty Molepske moves the report of Dr Galli into evidence; received by the Court.
2:40 p.m.  Atty Molepske gives his argument.
2:42 p.m.  Atty Slattery gives his argument.

BY THE COURT:
Based on the report of Dr Galli the defendant is found COMPETENT to stand trial.
  Preliminary hearing scheduled for August 10, 2015 at 01:30 pm.

Defendant Larry Sanchez in court with attorney Travis Stephen Slattery and Emily Nowlan Plutchak . Defendant Larry Sanchez in custody. Louis J. Molepske and Elizabeth Constable appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

11:45 AM Court calls case.
Atty Molepske states appearances.

This matter is before the Court at this time regarding the issue of competency.
Court asks the Defendant and counsel for Defendant if wish to, whether Defendant claims to be competent or incompetent.

Atty Slattery states that his client claims to be incompetent.

Court refers to the doctor's report.

Counsel and the Court have agreed to schedule this hearing for next month.

Atty Slatter requests additional evaluation, requests the Court to appoint another person to do another evaluation.

BY THE COURT:
Court denies the request.

Department of Health Services was appointed by the Court to do the evaluation.

State has complied with victim notification statutes.

Atty Molepske addresses the Court. 

BY THE COURT:
Bond is ordered continued.
